docs.snippet: For Shamir and his friends, money is tight, boredom is pervasive and trouble is easy to find....
docs.lead_paragraph: For Shamir and his friends, money is tight, boredom is pervasive and trouble is easy to find.
docs.abstract: Fifteen-year-old Shamir is a resident of the Brownsville neighborhood of Brooklyn, New York's poorest neighborhood and one of its most violent; typical day for Shamir is characterized by boredom, which many attribute to the high rate of crime among the neighborhood's young men.

docs.snippet: When the final buzzer sounded on the longest week of the Los Angeles Clippers' careers, they felt more exhaustion than elation. While coach Doc Rivers high-fived fans and pumped his fist at the crowd, Blake Griffin and Chris Paul quietly congratul...
docs.lead_paragraph: When the final buzzer sounded on the longest week of the Los Angeles Clippers' careers, they felt more exhaustion than elation. While coach Doc Rivers high-fived fans and pumped his fist at the crowd, Blake Griffin and Chris Paul quietly congratulated each other.

headline.main: Clippers Hold Off Warriors 126-121 to Win Game 7

docs.snippet: The economic catastrophe of 2008 was the largest of its kind since the Depression. Who’s taking the fall?...
docs.lead_paragraph: The economic catastrophe of 2008 was the largest of its kind since the Depression. Who’s taking the fall?
docs.abstract: Fact that Kareem Serageldin, former executive at Credit Suisse, was the only Wall Street executive sent to jail for his part in the financial crisis reflects many of the paradoxes that led to the 2008 crisis in the first place; part of the reason Justice Dept failed to secure convictions is that a series of corporate prosecutorial fiascoes led to critical changes in how it approached white-collar crime.

headline.main: Why Only One Top Banker Went to Jail for the Financial Crisis
